Description: Cypriot terracotta figure of robed man with beard and headdress. Flat mould-made ‘Asiatic’, or ‘Assyrian’ man. Pressed into one-piece mould. Robe, face and headdress painted red, beard and details painted black. Pale buff/grey fabric with fine black and white inclusions.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Temple of Aphrodite (Naukratis), Context Φ17
Curator's comments: Such ‘Asiatic’ looking male figurines date to between the mid 7th to late 6th centuries BC, with very close parallels from Cyprus, probably from Arsos workshops (Karageorghis 1995, 19-21, Type I(ii)47. pl. 10.4, and similar examples from Arsos Type I(ii)38. pl. 9.3). Karageorghis argues the ‘Assyrian’ look may coincide with Assyrian domination of Cyprus during the seventh century BC (1995, 21). See EA 50126, 50127, 50128, 50130 (EA 1911,0710.102, 1911,0710.103, 1911,0710.105) also from Naukratis. Karageorghis, V. 1995. The coroplastic art of ancient Cyprus. IV. The Cypro-Archaic Period small male figurines. Nicosia, University of Cyprus.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DA.038) (Phase 1)
